posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
KrayonCAD is a collection of configurable Onshape assemblies designed for rapid prototyping of common FIRST Robotics subsystems. These subsystems enable quick and efficient assembly creation by focusing on key components with minimal detail. KrayonCAD simplifies the design process, allowing users to transition swiftly from initial concepts to 3D models.

KrayonCAD features a library of ready-to-use assemblies that cover essential FRC mechanisms. Users can explore subsystems based on color coding corresponding to the default Onshape palette. For instance, subsystems like Structure/Arm are red, providing clear visual distinction. This system supports early-stage design workflows, facilitating swift development and modification.

To utilize KrayonCAD, users can insert, configure, and mate subsystems effectively. Configurations vary per component type, supporting mates like Fasten and Revolute for seamless integration. The library spans numerous categories, including Drivebases, Structure/Arm, Shooters, Indexers, Turret, Intakes, Elevator, and Zone. Each category follows its designated color scheme for easy identification.

Despite its efficiency, KrayonCAD is not a complete CAD solution. Traditional CAD tools remain essential for intricate details and precise geometry verification. Users should opt for KrayonCAD as the initial step in their design journey, complemented by additional tools for more complex projects.

Contributions to KrayonCAD were made by several individuals, each playing unique roles in its development. Key contributors include Nick.kremer, AndrewCard, Astro_6423, bcon, apoorva, Connor-8177, DoopSheep, and jlr. Their efforts have significantly enhanced the project, making it accessible to a broader audience.

This introduction highlights KrayonCAD's role in accelerating robotics design, emphasizing its utility for teams of varying experience levels. By providing pre-configured components, it streamlines the transition from conceptualization to full-scale modeling.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text, preserving only the essential content while removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements: ---

KrayonCAD

The development team created KrayonCAD to showcase innovative robots every year from 2011 to 2023. Each entry highlights significant advancements in robot design and functionality.

• 2011: 1114 models released

• 2012: 1717 models released

• 2013: 1538 models released

• 2014: 254 models released

• 2015: 148 models released

• 2016: 330 models released

• 2017: 125 models released

• 2018: 118 models released

• 2019: 971 models released

• 2020: 1690 models released

• 2022: 4414 models released

• 2023: 1323 models released

--- This version removes all unnecessary formatting and focuses solely on the key information presented in a more concise and organized manner.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: In this video, I demonstrate the KrayonCAD workflow by recreating Robot #254 from 2011. The video features the YouTube thumbnail image at https://img.youtube.com/vi/bD2al3lmBeU/hqdefault.jpg, with the full URL accessible at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bD2al3lmBeU&t=503.

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked: Excited to see what people create with this! Just started a cadathon, and let's just say being able to bring an idea to life as a robot in about 10 minutes is absolutely amazing. Glad to have worked on this with such incredible people.

posts.name: Marcus
posts.cooked: Yep. We’re in. Great resource! Thanks, Nick
This is excellent, something I never considered integrating into an OS library. Our kids will love it. Making CAD less daunting and frustrating for children is a big win in my opinion.

posts.name: Ricky Marcus
posts.cooked: This is so cool! Already shared with my team!

posts.name: Chris Mounts
posts.cooked: This is great for conceptual design! Thanks for sharing. Only took about 10 minutes to mock up a quick concept.

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked: MRN: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dWiT4jT1NWU opens in new tab

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: Thanks Marcus, MKCAD was obviously a huge inspiration for this project!

posts.name: David Powers
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

Nick and team,

We took some time to experiment and built a quick mockup of the 2011 concept. It turned out surprisingly efficient—building the entire robot only took us ten minutes! We’re really impressed with how versatile and useful this tool is. We plan on integrating it into our curriculum early in the season to give students hands-on experience with different architectural concepts. The effort you put in is truly appreciated. Thanks for everything!

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: Dave, that’s cool and all, but no picture? Come on man!

posts.name: David Powers
posts.cooked: I'll have the students post some screenshots in our OA thread; don't want to spoil their work.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: The fair enough haha.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: A feature request has been submitted for a pink arm pivot that doesn’t require an A frame. The design incorporates the pivot mechanism directly into the arm, facilitating seamless integration with a custom frame.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Thanks for creating this tool. This should be a valuable resource for teams. I will ask our CAD team to try it out. What function/mechanism is "8. Zoning"?

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked:
I could've sworn we had this. Let me check.

Yeah, ElliotS, if you scroll down in the configs, you can make it so it has no A-frame.

ElliotS says you can tweak the config to remove the A-frame entirely. Here's the image for reference.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: These are meant to help figure out height, extension restrictions. They are transparent so you can insert them into a KrayonCAD Assembly without obscuring the robot. Or you can make an egg.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: The No A-Frame option technically lacks a central pivot point, but practically, selecting an outermost tube's face allows you to mate it centrally via a connector on that face.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: I’ve watched this project evolve from a “what if” concept on Discord to the fully-fledged CAD library you now see. I’m thrilled with the team’s accomplishment and look forward to integrating this into our design process!
